text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits a revised IRM 8.17.7, Penalties/Additions to Tax in Computations.
The following editorial changes were made in this IRM:
a. IRM
: The wording “prior to” in paragraph (
)(a) changed to “on or before”. b. IRM
, paragraph (
): Changed “filed” to “due”. c. IRM
, paragraphs (
)(b) and (c): Changes made to clarify procedures. d. IRM
, paragraphs (
)(a) and (d): The wording “prior to” in the first sentence of paragraph (
)(a) changed to “on or before”. Deleted the last sentence of paragraph (
)(a) and all of paragraph (
)(d) since IRC
only applies to filed returns.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS This supersedes IRM 8.17.7 dated 9/24/2013.
Appeals employees who prepare settlement computations involving penalties and/or additions to tax.
Lisa Zannitto Acting Director, Policy, Quality and Case Support

to Tax in Computations 8.17.7

) This subsection briefly discusses the various penalties and additions to tax are included in settlement computations. These penalties and additions to with tax are generally considered by Appeals concurrently with the tax liability and Additions erating the penalty or addition to tax amounts. (
) For detailed information on these penalties and additions to tax, see IRM Penalty Handbook. (
) The more common penalties and additions to the tax by Code section and of tax are summarized in the Penalty Reference Chart found in the exhibit. Exhibit

) For useful information about penalty computations, click on the “Procedures and Resources” link on the Tax Computation Specialist (TCS) web site, and then see the “Penalty Information” folder. (cid:

) This folder has a file with a very helpful chart which discusses whether certain penalties can be asserted on a deficiency determined in depending on if the return was timely filed, late filed, or is a Substitute Return (SFR) case. (cid:
) The file also contains flow charts to assist in determining whether or not certain penalties can be asserted on a deficiency determined in (
) References to an Appeals Officer (AO) within this IRM section include both AO and an Appeals Team Case Leader (ATCL). (

) In most cases, penalty provisions of the code sections in effect for the loss year generating the carryback govern penalties applicable to carryback Impacting the for deficiencies due to a carryback recapture. Computations (
) Net operating loss carrybacks, capital loss carrybacks and all credit cannot be used to reduce the underpayment subject to the penalty. (

) Prepayment credits and frozen refunds may impact the penalty a. Prepayment credits are payments of tax such as withholding tax, estimated tax payments, etc., made on or before the due date of the return. Prepayment credits also include payments made on or before due date for an unfiled return. b. Prepayment credits do not include advance payments, cash bonds, or amounts applied from other tax liabilities subsequent to the due date of the return for which the penalty applies. c. Payments and credits from a filed return that are neither applied to a liability nor refunded to the taxpayer are called “frozen refunds”, and also impact the penalty computations. (
) The following penalties were repealed for returns due (without regard to sions) after

to Tax in Computations 8.17.7

a. If valid extensions of time to file have been granted, the FTF penalty is applicable until the expiration of the extension and then only from that date on. An extension may be considered invalid if tax is not properly estimated. In these instances, the FTF penalty is computed from the original due date. b. To arrive at the tax liability required to be shown on return, compute the revised tax liability of the case, excluding all net operating loss, capital loss and credit carrybacks. c. All withholding credits are considered timely paid regardless of the posting date shown on the IDRS transcript. Additional withholding credits are considered timely paid and are allowed as credits when computing delinquency penalty. d. Refundable credits such as earned income credit, additional child tax credit, first time homebuyer credit, etc:
Are treated as payments when computing the FTF penalty.
Adjustments made to change these credits are not included in the revised tax liability.

Instead, when computing the FTF penalty with adjustments to these credits, the revised tax liability as determined in paragraph (b) above is reduced by the allowable amount of these refundable credits.
The “allowable” amount of refundable credit is the total amount shown on the transcript increased or decreased by any adjustments made to the re- fundable credit in the Appeals tax computation.

Adjustments made to change these credits are not included in the tax liability. Instead, when computing the FTF penalty with adjustments to these credits, the revised tax liability as determined in paragraph (b) above is reduced by the allowable amount of these refundable credits. The “allowable” amount of refundable credit is the total amount shown the transcript increased or decreased by any adjustments made to the fundable credit in the Appeals tax computation.
) The FTF penalty is generally computer generated by the Campus with to the liability shown on delinquent returns. (
) Generally Appeals computations that assert the IRC
penalty use the penalty schedules or the TCS Excel penalty spreadsheets on the Support Shar
oint site, reached by a link on the TCS web site. (

) Interest will be imposed on the FTF penalty as of the return due date (including extensions.) The Campus will normally compute interest. If the taxpayer wishes to make a payment, then an interest computation will be requested by the AO and included in the case file. (
) Additional information on computing the FTF penalty can be found in IRM
, Failure To File/Failure To Pay Penalties. (
) If the return is at least
days late, including extensions, a minimum FTF penalty applies: (cid:
) For returns due (without regard to extensions) after
, the minimum penalty is the lesser of $
or
percent of the tax be shown on the return that was not paid on or before the due date. (cid:
) For returns due (without regard to extensions) before
, the minimum penalty is the lesser of $
or
percent of the tax be shown on the return that was not paid on or before the due date. (

) In order for the minimum penalty to apply, there must be a net tax due. holding and other allowable credits as of the due date of the return must less than the revised tax liability or tax required to be shown on the return.
(cid:
) For returns due (without regard to extensions) after
, the minimum penalty is the lesser of $
or
percent of the tax required to be shown on the return that was not paid on or before the due date. (cid:
) For returns due (without regard to extensions) before
, the minimum penalty is the lesser of $
or
percent of the tax required to be shown on the return that was not paid on or before the due date.

In order for the minimum penalty to apply, there must be a net tax due. With- holding and other allowable credits as of the due date of the return must be less than the revised tax liability or tax required to be shown on the return.
8.17 Settlement Computations and Statutory Notices of Deficiency
The minimum penalty applies only to income tax returns. It does not apply to employment tax, excise tax, gift tax, or estate tax returns.
If the failure to file is due to fraud, the fraudulent failure to file penalty under IRC 6651(f) may be asserted rather than the regular FTF penalty under IRC

Failure to Pay Penalty - $500.00 x 1/2 of 1% for 8 months
Failure to File Penalty - $500.00 x 5% per month for 5 months.

page Exception: In certain circumstances the FTP penalty may be computed at the maximum rate when the penalty is still accruing. An example is when Counsel or the AO determines that the FTP penalty should be computed at the maximum

) IRC
(f) provides for an increase in the penalty rate for failure to file if failure to file is fraudulent. The penalty rate is increased from
percent per month to
percent for each month or part of a month the return is late, and the maximum penalty is increased from
percent of the amount subject to IRC
) to
percent of that amount. (
) The IRC
(f) fraudulent failure to file (FFTF) penalty is a counterpart of IRC
civil fraud penalty. The fraud components of the FFTF penalty and the civil fraud penalty are generally similar: (cid:
) The civil fraud penalty requires an underpayment which is attributable to the willful and knowing intent to defraud. (cid:
) The FFTF penalty requires that all or part of the tax required to be shown on the return was unpaid on the due date for payment. (
) The FFTF penalty and the IRC
civil fraud penalty can be asserted on same return, if failure to file is due to fraud and the taxpayer files a return a deficiency attributable to fraud. (
) Additional information on the fraudulent failure to file penalty can be found in IRM
, Failure To File/Failure To Pay Penalties. Internal Revenue Manual
to Tax in Computations 8.17.7

) The civil fraud penalty requires an underpayment which is attributable to the willful and knowing intent to defraud. (cid:

) A percentage of the prior year’s tax.

Facts: The taxpayers filed their joint 2006 return on August 19, 2008. The tax liability on the return was $4,062.00. The taxpayer had withholding of $726.00, resulting in net tax due of $3,336.00. FTF and FTP penalties were assessed by the Campus as shown below:
FTP Penalty Assessed: 3,336.00 x .005/month x 17 months
Note: It may appear that the Campus computed the FTF penalty using a rate of .045 per month, since 3,336.00 x .045/month x 5 months = $750.60. However, the actual computation is shown above.
The return was examined and an additional tax deficiency of $1,500.00 was determined. The additional IRC 6651(a)(1) penalty would be $375.00, computed as shown below:
Additional failure to file penalty
